name: Hotel Ukraine

reviews.text: Try to get a room with a view of Independence Square if you stay here!
reviews.title: Good value in a great location -- quirky procedures + limited English proficiency.

reviews.text: This hotel is a good value (with the exchange rates in effect in fall 2009) and a great location overlooking Independence Square, which features shopping, restaurants, and a subway stop. It has modernized many rooms but apparently not all of them completely. The rooms are clean and adequately-sized with some decent furniture.
reviews.title: OK Hotel

reviews.text: However, the hotel was built several decades ago. It has a dingy lobby, slow elevators, and unusual procedures not often seen in the West (for example, you need to show a passport to check in, but need to pay before getting your passport back). In the guest rooms, the sleeping areas seem to be recently renovated, but the restrooms, particularly the shower facilities and toilets, show their age.
reviews.title: Certainly a unique experience...

reviews.text: Visitors speaking English only are advised to stay elsewhere. The staff is generally courteous and hard-working but seem to have little patience for English-speakers.
reviews.title: Great location not so great staff

reviews.text: Tried to find a reasonable price well-located hotel in Kiev. The Ukraina is well located. Rooms are more likely clean, but you feel like back in the 70s: completely outdated and soviet-styled. Breakfast OK. Free porn on TV - never seen this feature in any "real" hotel. If I could, would pay USD 400 for Hyatt or Intercontinental.
reviews.title: Not my cup of tea...

reviews.text: It was my third visit to this great City and ever since I saw the Ukraina on Television during the Orange Revolution of Winter 2004/2005 I wanted to stay at this Hotel.
reviews.title: What else does one need?

reviews.text: I was a bit apprehensive because of all the bad reports. So let me tell you all about my experience in just a few words:
reviews.title: Location is everything!!!!!

reviews.text: Location:
reviews.title: Above average 3 star hotel great location.

reviews.text: Perfect, the best located Hotel I ever stayed in (and I stayed in thousands). The magnificant Square of Independence right in front of the Hotel, Shopping a few steps away in an air conditioned mall (what a relief at 40 degress Celcius), several Restaurants within 200 Meters, Kreschatik Street right in front....perfect!
reviews.title: Not bad. Good location.

reviews.text: Rooms:
reviews.title: Not Bad, and a Great Location

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: After spending a week in Russia we had similar expectations for Kiev, but Ukraina was pretty good. We got a renovated room - spacious and although it definitely wasn't our taste, it was a good hotel room. The staff were very helpful, and spoke English - which we didn't expect at all. Brilliant location overlooking the square.
reviews.title: Way better than we expected

likes.disliked: — Breakfast - why do they never top up the buffett?????

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My wife and I just returned from Ukraine and stayed 1 night. Our room was on the 11th floor overlooking Independence Square and we couldn't have been happier. Our room was a "junior suite" that had a very comfortable double bed and even a small balcony. The most important feature of the room (considering we went in July) was that it had air conditioning which is not a feature of every room!
reviews.title: I recommend it to anyone!

likes.liked: — Convenience - it is right on Independence Square

reviews.text: The price of the room was about 900 UAH which is roughly $200.00 and that includes breakfast.
reviews.title: Next time hope would be better!

reviews.text: The bottom line here as with any hotel in Europe, ask to see the room BEFORE you register. This is a very common practice and they will not be insulted.
reviews.title: Could be a lot worse

likes.disliked: — The bathroom, although it seems to vary depending on the floor

reviews.text: Ok i know the hotel has changed much since one year ago.. But when i was there for 7days which seemed to a life time almost.. There was only the first two floors renovated up again.. I was half way up of the hotel ( cant remeber number of floor). The view was totally excellent! best i had for ages to be honest, as it was looking of the main sqaure and shopping area.. Well that was the only good thing really. The window was stuffed with foam and tape so i am not sure if that was to keep the window from falling out or the the cold out?..The staff was hard work as they did not know much English at all close to none really.. The front desk could not smile and even say enjoy your stay!..Mind you that would of been a joke in its self really.. The room is the worse i ever stayed in.. God i was in shock!.. The room was dity/dusty.. The bed was stained and not enough covers as it was very cold..The heating only came on for a few hours! which was normally when no one was in the hotel rooms.. There was a key lady on each floor to hand the keys as you went in and out. Problem was she was never there and if you left the key anyone could pick it up after if you left it on the desk.. I decide to keep my key all times.. This did not go down well with the key lady at all the fasle smile turned to anger!.. Every night people tried to enter my room but i always leave in the key in the door for safely, that made me nervous a little at night time... The bathroom was not fit to use at all..The toilet was not clean with a dirty plastic seat on it.. The tiles was mouldy with no plus in bath or sink..The towels felt rough and most of them was stained even when clean!. I felt sick using the bathroom.. The food i did not try after the rest of the hotel, i always went out ot eat which was great!... The city was good and great to see thou... Hotel was bad! i hope now things have improved as it could be a great hotel!
reviews.title: one night was enough

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I reserved a room for myself and my girlfriend who is Ukrainian for three nights. Unfortunately, she could not meet me on the first day so I checked in by myself. The next day when she arrived she forgot to bring her passport. When we went up to our room we were stopped by the lady that keeps your key (you turn your key in to a lady present at every floor when you leave an annoying rule where they track your movement in and out) and told that my girlfriend had to register in the main lobby. Fine, no problem, we said. When we went downstairs to the main floor we were met by the rudest reception woman I have ever known! She said that my girlfriend could not stay as she did not have her passport with her. When I asked where she was to stay the night (she lives six hours away) the woman responded it was our problem! I asked for the hotel manager and the woman refused to contact him/her. Fortunately another woman (much kinder with better customer service) approached us and offered a compromise. She said she could stay the night so long as I wrote a statement giving permission and she faxed a copy of her passport in the morning. My girlfriend later told me the rude woman had made comments that she was a prostitute staying for the night!
reviews.title: Stay Away

reviews.text: Never will I stay at this hotel as this has been the worst experience at any hotel including other cities in Ukraine and Russia.
reviews.title: Back to the USSR

reviews.text: The location is also negated by the walk up from the main street. The hotel stands on a hill and the walk up gets tiring very quickly.
reviews.title: Frustrating and stressful

reviews.text: So. You land at Borispil, and friendly old Viktor picks you up to ferry you into town. Through the slush, across the Dniepr, up Kreschatik, he ferries you up to Independence Square. There, set off proudly against the gloom, the letters "Hoteli Ukraina" greet you right across from the Independence Column Shopping Centre (you're in Ukraine, so no "gastinitsa" here sir, oh no). A solid block of Stalinist concrete-and-granite, the Ukraina must at one stage have played host to the gratin of Donetsk, the delegates of the Moldovan SSR Young Pioneers, or a fraternal exchange of meritorious workers from the Dushanbe Red October tschotchka factory. Today, of course, the successful members of these groups are all staying at the Radisson, while their less successful comrades are stuck to the bottom of a cheap bottle in some place neither you nor I have ever heard of, and hopefully never will.
reviews.title: The Old Lady of Independence Square

likes.liked: — The whole experience. . . and then the location.

reviews.text: So what keeps the Ukraina going, you ask? You and me. The poor sods who just go there for lack of anything better to try. We learn our lesson, and move on - but others will fill our shoes, and the Ukraina, with its overstuffed white leather armchairs; its thuggish, er.. "security guards"; its pole-dancing joint (only place open for a drink after seven PM) and its seemingly limitless supply of young, lissome, and definitely underdressed young ladies on every floor, will stay in business. It will probably bury us all.
reviews.title: Nice hotel

description: Четырехзвездочная гостиница "Украина" расположена в центре Киева на Майдане Незалежности. В гостинице 371 номер различных категорий, которые соответствуют всем требованиям комфорта и доступны по стоимости проживания. К вашим услугам конференц-залы, рестораны и банкетные залы, суши-бар, салон красоты, сауна, бизнес-центр, автостоянка и бесплатный WiFi в номерах и общественных зонах гостиницы
